There were two other indictments against the prisoner for the man-slaughter of the other persons upon which
no evidence was offered.)

1767.
GOSMAN MYERS was indicted
for unlawfully uttering coun
terfeit coin.

JOHN HALL . I keep a beer-shop in Battersea-marsh. On the 31st of July the prisoner came to my shop at near nine o'clock, and asked for a pot of ale—he gave me a bad half-crown—I detained it, took the beer from him, and cautioned him to go no further, or I expected he would be taken—I did not stop him, I gave him another chance—I wrapped the half-crown up in a piece of paper, marked it, and afterwards gave it to Jackson.

Prisoner. Q. Did not you call your wife to look at a young lad at the bar? A. No; my wife was not there—you did not tender me 6d. for the beer—I have no recollection of seeing a youth there—I am confident you gave me the half-crown.

LOUISA STEVENS . My husband, Thomas Stevens, keeps a booth. On the evening of the 31st of July we were at Battersea-fair—as it was getting dark the prisoner came and asked for a pot of half-and-half—I set it down on the counter—he threw down a half-crown—I took it up, saw it was bad, and gave it to my husband—May was there at the time, and took hold of the prisoner, and took him into custody.

THOMAS STEVENS . I am the last witness's husband. On Thursday, the 31st of July, my wife gave me a half-crown—I gave it to the police
man, who took the prisoner into custody.

JOHN MAY (policeman.) On the 31st of July I was in Stevens's booth about ten o'clock, and saw the prisoner there—I saw him put a half-crown on the counter—Mrs. Stevens picked it up, and put it on the counter again—her husband took it up, and gave it to me—it was never out of my sight—I produce it—I took the prisoner into custody, searched him, and found 18d. in a tobacco-box, and 6d., but no bad money.

HENRY JACKSON (policeman.) I produce two half-crowns; one I re
ceived from Hall, and one from May.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Mint. These two half-crowns are both counterfeit, and both cast in the same mould.

GUILTY .*—
Confined Six Months.

1768.
JOHN BURKE was indicted
for unlawfully uttering and having in his possession counterfeit coin.

MARK SAUNDERSON . I am barman to Mr. Griffiths, of the Rising Sun, York-road, Lambeth. On the 15th of July, about half-past one o'clock, the prisoner came, asked for half a pint of beer, and offered a bad sixpence in payment—I said, "This is a bad one; do you know it?"—he said he did not—I asked if he had any more money—he said no—I asked where he got it—he said from a man named Simmons, a plasterer—I asked him where Simmons lived—he said he did not know—I then told him I should know where Mr. Simmons lived before I let him go—I let him go out, followed him a quarter of a mile, and gave him in charge to Hughes—I held the sixpence in my hand till then, then bit it, and gave it to him.

JAMES HUGHES (policeman.) Saunderson gave the prisoner into my custody by the Cornwall-road—I searched him, and found five other bad sixpences in the corner of the collar of his coat, wrapped up in this piece of paper—he had a good 4d. piece, and a penny on him—this other sixpence I received from Saunderson after he marked it
MR. JOHN FIELD . These sixpences are all counterfeit, and cast in the same mould.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not know they were bad; I picked them up; if I had known they were bad I could have thrown them away; I work. hard for my living, and have a wife and family.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined Six Months.

1769.
HENRY SHERLOCK the younger, was indicted
for stealing 1 pair of trowsers, value 7s.; 1 cap, 1s.; and 1 waistcoat, 2s.; the goods of
Henry Sherlock; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .* Aged 17.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1770.
JOHN PARKER was indicted
for stealing 141bs. weight of lead, value 2s., the goods of
James Easton and another, his masters; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Six Months.

1771.
JAMES DENNIS was indicted
for stealing 1 flannel-jacket, value 2s., the goods of
George Frost; and that he had been before con
victed of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Six Months.

1772.
JAMES FLEMING was indicted
for stealing 1 metal castor, value 4d.; 2 hinges, 6d.; 1lb. weight of lead, 2d.; and 1lb. weight of brass, 8d.; the goods of
Stephen Lane Blakeborough, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Four Months.

1773.
MICHAEL LINAN was indicted for
stealing 1 shawl, value 5s.; 1 handkerchief, 2s. 6d.; and 1 pair of boots, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Catherine Turner; and
ANN WHITE
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.: to which

LINAN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 14.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined Three Months.

CATHERINE TURNER . I am a widow, and live in Windmill-street, New-cut, Lambeth. On the 5th of Aug. I went out in the morning—I locked my room door—I left a shawl, a handkerchief, and a pair of boots in my box—when I returned, I found my box was broken open, and Ihese things were gone—these are them.
HENRY ATKINS . I am shopman to Mr. Young, a pawnbroker. This shawl, handkerchief, and boots were pawned by the prisoner White.

THOMAS WILLIAM REDFORD (police-constable L 52.) I apprehended White—I asked her if she knew what I came for—she said, with an oath, that she did, and if I had not come as I did, she should have been off—she said a boy brought these things to her to pawn.

White's Defence. Linan was in the habit of coming to my place—I knew him as a neighbour's child—he came that morning, and asked me to take these things to pawn—I said, "Why don't you take them?"—he said, "I am not old enough, they won't take them in of me"—I said, "Where did you get them?"—he said, "A man gave them to me."

WHITE—
NOT GUILTY .

1774.
ELIZA UPTON and
LOUISA CODE were indicted for
stealing 4 half-crowns, the monies of
Charles Goldsmith, from his person.

CHARLES GOLDSMITH . I live in Dacre-street, Westminster, and am a saddler. On the night of the 3rd of Aug., at twelve o'clock, I was going down Stangate-street—I met the two prisoners—they stood in the middle of the path, and said, "My dear, where are you going?"—they seized hold of me, and took all sorts of liberties with me—while Upton was taking liberties with me, Code picked my pocket of four half-crowns—I put my hand to my pocket where I had had four half-crowns, and I missed them—I perceived that Code had robbed me, because Upton held me while Code picked my pocket—the money was in my right-hand waistcoat pocket—I called, "Police;" and two men immediately flew from some door-way to the prisoners—there seemed like some conversation with them, and something was handed—one of the men ran off—the other came to me, and said, "Don't be alarmed, I will protect you"—I would not leave the prisoners—they shuffled into another street, to get away from me, but I would not leave them—I said, "You have robbed me;" and they made a sort of jeer of it—the policeman came up, and I gave them in charge.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. How were you, pretty sober? A. Yes, I had not been drinking—I had been to my brother's, at Ken
nington—I had left there about a quarter to twelve, and was going home

—I have gone by the name of William Anderson, which was a nick-name of the boys when I went to school—I have called myself William Ander-son—I did so when I was at the police-court, because I did not like my name exposed in the newspaper—I am a journeyman saddler—I swore my name was William Anderson, but it was because I was confused—my mother's name was Anderson—the boys knew that, and I went by my mother's name.

JOHN DAVIES (police-constable L 46.) I was on duty in Stangate-street—I heard a cry of "Police"—I went up and saw the prosecutor and the prisoners—he gave them in charge—I met another officer—I gave Code to him, and I took Upton—she said to me, "Did he give me in charge for taking half-a-sovereign?"—I said, "I don't know"—she said, "Has not he had it back again?"—I said, "I don't know"—the prose
cutor told me what they took from him, and that Code took it—the pro
secutor was perfectly sober.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he appear excited? A. Yes.

UPTON—
GUILTY . Aged 38.

CODE—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

1775.
THOMAS ATKINS was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
James Everett.

JAMES EVERETT . I am a gingerbread
baker. I had a booth in Batter-sea-fair—I had a great-coat at the front of the booth, between the canis-ters and a chair—I am confident it was safe about half-past five o'clock, and I missed it afterwards—I did not see the prisoner there—this is my coat.

JOHN MAY (police-constable V 281.) About seven o'clock in the even-ing, on the 1st of Aug., I saw the prisoner come along by the side of a willow hedge by the Thames, and he put a bundle which he had into the hedge—he went on to the bridge, and then he went and took the bundle out of the hedge, and went on to the Steam-boat Pier—I took him, and found this coat under his arm.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the coat, and was going to take it to the station-house.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined One Month.

1776.
HENRY CHIDGEY was indicted
for stealing five loaves of bread, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 apron, 4d.; the goods of
James William Ritchie, his master.

JAMES WILLIAM RITCHIE . I am a baker, and live at Walwortb. The prisoner was my apprentice. On the night of the 6th of August, I was in my bakehouse—I observed a light in my yard—I saw the gate partly open—I went round to a turning that the yard gate opens into, and saw the prisoner looking out into the turning—I crept behind my barrow, which stood in the turning—I saw the prisoner with a bundle, which he put into the barrow—he then went into the gate and fastened it—I called my next neighbour, and as the prisoner was coming out the front way I took him—I then went to the barrow, and found this apron which I had worn the same evening, and in it were five loaves—I spoke to the prisoner about it—he said, "Pray let me go"—he had no business to put bread into the barrow at that time of night.
GEORGE PENYER (police-constable P 201.) I took the prisoner—he
said he did take the bread, that it his wages were so small they were not sufficient to maintain his wife, and he meant to take the bread to his wife.
Prisoner's Defence. My master only allowed me 5s. a week to keep myself and my wife.
MR. RITCHIE re-examined. He was hoarded and lodged in my house—he had 5s. a week, and 1s. a week perquisite beside.

GUILTY .* Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1777.
JOHN DAVIS was indicted
for stealing a flute, value 1l. 15s., the goods of
Henry Ray Wilcocke; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Three Months.

1778.
GEORGE WRIGHT,
WILLIAM BAYLIS , and
FREDE
RICK DIBBIN , were indicted for
stealing 1 sixpence, and 2 groats; the monies of
George Collins.

GEORGE COLLINS . I am a grocer, and live in Kennington-place. On the 1st of Aug., a few minutes after ten o'clock, I was leaving my shop to go into the parlour behind—when I got to the parlour door I heard some money rattle—I turned and saw Baylis leaning on the counter on his elbows, with a halfpenny in his hand—he asked me for a halfpenny-worth of Negrohead tobacco—I said I did not sell it—he then turned, and was about to leave the shop—I looked into my till, and found all the money was gone—I missed a sixpence and two fourpenny pieces, which I had put in the minute before, and what other money there had been in it I do not know—I jumped over the counter, ran round the cor
ner, and caught Baylis in Devonshire-place—my house is the corner house but one to Devonshire-place—I saw Dibbin was just parting from him—I took Baylis back—I said, "I want that money you have taken out of my till"—he said, "What money?"—he said he had none about him—I said, "You have given it to that other chap"—Dibbin was then in the road—he had come back, and was standing near my door—Baylis called to him and said, "Fred.," and Dibbin ran away—after he was gone, Baylis said, "If you will come with me I will take you to the place where the money is"—I said I would keep him—he then ran off, I ran after him up Kennington-lane, and he was taken again.

THOMAS JONES . I am waiter at the Queen's Arms, in Kennington-lane. About ten o'clock that morning I saw the three prisoners standing at the corner of Vauxhall-street, right opposite the prosecutor's shop—I saw Baylis and Dibbin leave Wright on the other side of the way, and come across to Mr. Collins's shop—I saw Baylis go inside, and Dibbin was standing outside—I then went in
doors, and in a few minutes I went into Devonshire-street, and saw Baylis and Dibbin come down the street, and Baylis gave Dibbin some silver—Mr. Collins then came round the corner, he pursued Baylis and took him—Dibbin then went and gave something to Wright, and they went off together—Dibbin came and stood by Mr. Collins's shop—some person said, "That is the boy that was at the door," and he ran off.

THOMAS FARMER WILKINS (police-constable 89 L). I saw Mr. Collins pursue Baylis, and he cried, "Stop thief"—I took him, and Mr. Collins charged him with stealing money from the till—he denied it, but on the way to the station he said, "You b—rogue you think you have got him,
but you have not got him yet, and you cannot lag him for this"—he was very abusive all the way.
Wright's Defence. I never had any money.
Baylies Defence. I did not go to take anything; I went in for some tobacco, and turned out again.

WRIGHT*—
GUILTY . Aged 22

BAYLIS*—
GUILTY . Aged 18

DIBBIN*—
GUILTY . Aged 17

1779.
WILLIAM GALE and
JOHN COBBETT were indicted for
stealing 1 till, value 1s.; 4 shillings; 4 sixpences; 24 pence; 36 half-pence; and 24 farthings, the monies of
Philip William Margetts; and that Gale had been before convicted of felony.

COBBETT* pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Confined Six Months.

PHILIP WILLIAM MARGETTS . I am a beer-seller, and live at Vauxhall. On the 26th of July, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I left my bar to go into the kitchen—when I had been away about five minutes a boy came into my shop with my till, which was empty—when I had left ray shop I noticed the till was in front of the bar, with about 10s. in money in it—there were about 4 shillings, 4 sixpences, 24 pence, 36 halfpence, and 24 farthings—in consequence of information I went down Vauxhall-street, and informed the officer—I afterwards saw Gale in Sanderson-street, in custody—he threw a box behind him, but I did not see him.

CHARLES KENYON . I am an errand-boy, and live with my father—about five o'clock I saw Gale opposite the prosecutor's door—I knew him, and asked him to lift a basket off my head—while he was doing it Cobbett came out of Mr. Margett's shop with the till—he ran down Miller's-lane, and Gale followed him.

WILLIAM HENRY ALFRED GREEN . I live with my father—about five o'clock I was in Miller's-lane—I saw Cobbett with the till in his hand, and Gale followed him about half a dozen yards off—Cobbett then emptied the money into Gale's cap and threw the till away—they then ran away.

WILLIAM ATLEY (police-constable L 110.) I took Gale—he was charged with this, and denied it—as he was going along he chucked this box behind him, which contained one shilling and three sixpences—he said the money was his own—I took Cobbett on the Monday morning following.
Gale. I had nothing to do with it.

JAMES MURPHY (police-constable V 261.) I produce a certificate of Gale's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read—Convicted 28th March, 1845, and confined one month)—the prisoner is the person.

GALE—
GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1780.
JOHN WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing 1 purse, value 3s.; and 6 half-crowns; the property of
George Johnson, from the person of
Mary Johnson.

MARY JOHNSON . I am the wife of George Johnson, of Chelsea. On Tuesday evening, the 29th of July, about nine o'clock, I was with my husband at Clark's show, at Battersea fair—the prisoner stood by my side—I felt something fumbling at my pocket, and I saw his hand come out of my pocket with my purse—there were six half-crowns in it—he put it behind him—I called to my husband to hold him whilst I got a policeman.
Prisoner. Q. How far was I standing from you? A. Close to me—there was nobody there but you—there were plenty of people came round when I called out.
COURT. Q. There were other people about? A. Yes, by the side of the prisoner, but there was nobody behind me but him—there were plenty of people behind him, and on the other side of him.

JURY. Q. Did you see the hand coming out of your pocket? A. I did, with the purse in it, and he placed his hand behind him instantly—there were people near enough to have taken the purse from him—I am sure I saw it in his hand.

GEORGE JOHNSON . I was at the fair with my wife—I saw the prisoner on my left side—there were other persons behind him—my wife said, "This man has robbed me"—she had him by the jacket—I saw him in the act of drawing his hand from behind his back—he said, "Now you may search me if you like"—I slightly searched him, but found nothing.
Prisoner. Q. Did I move from where I was? A. He shifted about—I prevented his getting away—I have no doubt he would have got away if he could.

Prisoner's Defence. I was standing where I was, and she said, "I think this man has robbed me;" I said, "Do you think me?" and she said, "Yes;" I said, "Sir, if you think I have taken her purse, search me;" I never moved till the policeman came; the woman states there was no-body near, and what could I have done with the purse?

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1781.
WILLIAM POPE was indicted
for embezzling 16s., 1l. 5s., and 1l. 1s., which he received on account of
Benjamin Hoyle, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1782.
WILLIAM OWEN and
MARY OWEN were indicted for
steal-ing 1 pillow, value 2s.; 1 candlestick, 6d.; 2 pillow-cases, 6d.; 2 blankets, 6s.; and 1 sheet, 1s.; the goods of
John Ladd; to which

MARY OWEN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Three Months.

WILLIAM OWEN pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 23.

1783.
WILLIAM OWEN was again indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
William Cluse, on the 13th of June, and stealing 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 watch-chain, value 10s.; and 1 cash-box, 4s.; 10 sovereigns, 6 half-sovereigns, 8 half-crowns, 10 shillings, and 20 sixpences; his property; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1784.
JAMES JESSE TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing 1 bag, value 1s.; and 168lbs. weight of hair, 13s. 6d.; the goods of
David Morgan.

DAVID MORGAN . I am a builder, and live in the Old Kent-road. The prisoner was my plasterers' foreman—he was employed at weekly wages—I have some houses building in the Commercial-road, Peckham—he was employed there as foreman—I provided materials for the plastering, and among other things a quantity of hair—on the 17th of May I bought

2 cwt. of hair of Mr. Harmott—it was placed in Mr. Harmott's cart, and delivered at the buildings—I was present at the time—I paid 19s. for the hair the same day—it was the prisoner's business to receive it—I have the bill of it, which bears the prisoner's handwriting on it, showing that he received it at the building—when payment was required he was to put his name on the bill, and send it as a voucher, and I paid the money—I re-quired the prisoner to take the hair with other materials, to his lodging that he had taken, near the work—I considered it safer there, as several things had been lost from the buildings—some time after that, I saw the hair going towards the prisoner's lodgings—he had my truck under his care, and a labourer with him—on Monday, the 7th of June, I received information from Mr. Forbes, a gentleman living near there, and in conse
quence of that I discovered that a portion of my hair had been taken away—I missed about three-quarters of a cwt., which the prisoner ought to have had in his possession—I went and looked at the hair at Mr. Forbes's, and the sack—I cannot say that they were mine, nor could I swear to the hair or sack that were stolen—I expect the hair that I bought was of that sort and description, but I did not notice it when I purchased it—I did not see the prisoner on the day I went to look for the hair at his house—I saw him on Tuesday morning—I told him I wanted to know what was the reason he had left my work, and I said in the same sentence, "I understand you hare been selling a quantity of hair to Mr. Forbes, and what has become of the hair you had of mine?"—he got up in a hurry, and said be would let me know all about that, and left my house—I did not see him till the officer took him—he said on going out of the door that I had no business to trespass on his place, and he would serve a writ on me for the trespass I had committed in taking things from his lodging—I had taken my own scaffolding and other things from there—I did not see him again for ten days or a fortnight, when the officer brought him—the hair I bought was 2 cwt., and the quantity I authorized him to use about the work was about a quarter of a cwt.—I consider he would have had no occasion to use more than that—there should have been 1 cwt. 3/4 qrs. left.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. How long had he been in your employ? A. Between four and five months—he is a plasterer by trade—he has no shop—I paid him two guineas a week—I gave him into cus
tody about the 21st of July—about a week previous to that I had been served with a writ in an action of trespass—he was employed as my ser-vant, to superintend the plasterers' work at these houses in Commercial-road, Peckham, at one on Blackheath, one at Rye-lane, and one elsewhere—all of these he attended to—I swear that he had not entered into a con
tract with me to plaster these houses at a specific sum for each house—he was employed at Mr. Benbow's about March—he was not employed to do the plasterer's work at that gentleman's—he was then employed at those houses in the Commercial-road—it was at first six carcasses—I will swear I did not agree to pay him 18l. a house for that work—there was no written contract entered into between us in reference to that work, nor with reference to any houses—I directed him to plaster the outside of eighteen houses—he employed the workmen to plaster there, and he paid them their wages, but they were my servants—I authorized him to hire them—two of them came to me for a day and a quarter's wages on the last occasion—after the prisoner left the work, he went to them, and said he should have no more to do with them—they came to me, and I paid them—I
have got foremen similar to the prisoner, and they are all authorized to employ men—they all pay them, and the money they want I give them.

Q. Is it not usual for a plasterer to enter into this kind of contract, to do the work at a certain price, to obtain the goods on the credit of the builder, and to deduct the amount from the contract? A. I never heard of it, and nothing of that kind took place with me and the prisoner—Mr. Hook has contracted with a person to do the painting, and this work is a contract on my part—I took the work for 408l.

Q. But I want to know whether any of the plasterers that you employed were ever hired by you, or paid by you, except those two who called on you? A. No, except they came with him, and I gave him the money—I gave him the money for wages once, and I believe once or twice he had money for some beer—I think I gave him 6l. about the 6th of April.
Q. Have you not been served with a notice to bring your books here, and your contracts? A. That notice I took no notice of.
COURT. Q. You paid the prisoner the sum-total, and he doled it out to the different persons? A. Yes.
BENJAMIN SMITHERS . I am clerk to Mr. Robson. I served a notice on the prosecutor's sister, at his house.

MR. PARRY to DAVID MORGAN. Q. Do you undertake to swear that no written contract was ever delivered to you by the prisoner? A. I have sworn it—I do not know Mr. Franks—I do not know that I have ever seen him—I do not know Mr. Franks (looking at him)—I only saw him at the office—I never saw him at my counting-house in my life, or at any public-house in company with the prisoner—I swear there are no entries in my books to this effect, that I was to pay the prisoner so much for each house—I never heard of such a thing as the hard core from the mortar being the perqui-site of the builder—if he were to sell any of the remaining materials, I should consider it incorrect—there is hard core from the mortar after build-ing—it is very rarely sold—we are obliged sometimes to pay for taking it away—the prisoner had no authority from me to contract with any other parties to do this work—there were first six houses, and then eighteen, and then four small houses—I did not go to his house and seize on every-thing that I thought was mine—my things were in an open shed in the yard—I took my cart, and his wife pointed out the things that were mine—he did not use his own scaffolding, it was mine—my scaffolding was chiefly taken to my house, but some ropes and small things he took to his place for safety—when I charged him with taking this hair, he did not say It is my hair, you will be served with a writ of trespass"—he never an-swered me about the hair; but when I spoke of hair being sold, he said, "I will let you know all about that"—I did not give him into custody when I spoke to him about the hair, because I was not positive that he had stolen it—I was not as positive about it as I am now—I think I paid him 6l. on the 12th of April—I paid him from 6l. to about 32l. aweek, all for wages—I cannot tell exactly how many men were employed on that work—I used to go round each day and make a memorandum of how many men were employed—I paid the prisoner 6l., 12l., 20l., 28l., 31l. and 18l., I think, was the last.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. With regard to the hair and other materials, were they all yours and taken to his house for his convenience alone? A.

Yes, the ropes and scaffolding—I took all that belonged to me—they were used for this job or any other—I purchased a great many of them for this work, and I authorized the prisoner to hire some articles of a builder—I have got a receipt that I paid the builder for the hire of them—the prisoner hiring the men and I paying him the money for their wages is the usual course of business—I have four other men of different trades who work in the same way.

JOHN FORBES . I live at No. 3, Camden Villas, Camden
grove, Peck-ham, and am a builder—the prisoner came to me about the 20th of June and entered into a contract for building houses, and I was to find materials for the work—after he had entered into the contract, he said he had more bair than he wanted for Mr. Morgan's work, and asked me to take some—he said he had a two hundred weight bag—on the 27th of June he produced the hair to me, and I agreed to buy it at 9s. a hundred—I agreed to have one hundred and a half—he said that would be enough for my job—he then drew all the money he could on Saturday night, and left my job—I went to inquire where he was, and gave information to the prosecutor—the hair was all used except about a handful, which the policeman took away—I am sure what he took was some of the same hair that I had from the prisoner—the policeman took possession of the very same bag in which the hair was brought.

Cross-examined. Q. What was the contract you entered into? A. Seventeen pounds each house—that was for labour only—he represented to me that he had found all the materials for Mr. Morgan's job—I contracted with him to do these houses at so much per house—I had no quarrel with him, but he left my work in a most shameful manner, and took the scaffold-ing away; but I understand it belonged to Mr. Morgan.
CHARLES WHITE (police-constable P 57.) I produce some hair, and this bag which I brought from Mr. Forbes.

HENRY HARMOTT . My traveller sold 2 cwt. of hair to Mr. Mor-gan, and I directed a quantity of hair to be packed up from a heap in my warehouse—I have looked at this hair produced by the officer—there is nothing particular about it now, but when I saw it before in the officer's possession, previous to going before the magistrate, there was a small lock of seal-hair amongst it, and by some means it was lost—I took possession of it, but what became of it I cannot tell—in my warehouse in which the hair was which I directed to be packed up for Mr. Morgan, there was a great quantity of seal hair—it is probable that some of it might have got into that sent to Mr. Morgan, and I saw some of it in the hair produced by the officer—it would have been of no use to Mr. Morgan at all—I do not know of any one who sells hair to plasterers having seal hair—this hair produced is similar to what I had in bulk, and sold to Mr. Morgan.

Cross-examined. Q. You cannot say whether there was any seal-hair in that sent to Mr. Morgan? A. No. I did not see it packed up—the hair *—I sold to Mr. Morgan was received by the prisoner on the premises—I have frequently known plasterers to undertake to do work at so much per house, and for the builder to find the materials, and I have frequently known it done otherwise—the builder generally pays the bills.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Do you know of any case where the builder pays for the materials, and the workman takes the materials to sell to other parties? A. No—the hair I sent to Mr. Morgan was sent in a similar sack to this.

GEORGE HARMOTT . I am the son of Mr. Henry Harmott—I did not see the hair packed up for Mr. Morgan—I know this lack to be one of my father's by these knots that I tied at the corner, and this is the sack that went to Mr. Morgan's.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you take it? A. Yes.

JOHN FREDERICK FARNKS . I live in Castle-street, Shoreditch. I have been a builder in that neighbourhood twenty-seven years—I have known the prisoner nearly twenty years, and employed him—he is one of the honestest men I ever employed—I never knew Mr. Morgan till I saw him at a job once or twice—I remember the prisoner working for Mr. Morgan, and I want to the building and measured the work—I was pre
sent when the prisoner gave Mr. Morgan a contract for six houses—he said, "Mr. Morgan, that is the contract for six houses"—Mr. Morgan opened it and said, "It is all right, Taylor, you will hear from me"—I had seen the paper, and read it just before Mr. Morgan came into the public-house—the contents of it were to do the inside plastering of six houses, finding all materials, at 18l. a house—Mr. Morgan read it at the bar, and put it into his pocket—I afterwards gave the prisoner an estimate for plastering the outside of eighteen houses in the Commercial road—I was not present when Mr. Morgan and the prisoner had any conversation with reference to those houses—about April or May I sold the prisoner 2 cwt. of hair—I have sold him hair twenty times—he said he was paying 10s. for hair, and I said I could sell him some at 9s. 6d.
JURY Q. Do you deal in hair? A. No, but I have a great deal sometimes—when the prisoner is not employed I give him a job to work for me, and I find the materials—he is not a man of any capital.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Where did you buy this job of hair that you sold to the prisoner? A. I reajly cannot tell—I buy of a great many people—I will not tell you exactly where I bought it—it was on a Satur
day evening that I saw the prisoner give the prosecutor a paper—I think it was about the 12th of April—it was at the Nelson, a new public-house, between six and seven o'clock in the evening—it is on the right-hand side of the Kent-road, just through the gate—there were several other persons there, but none that I knew but Taylor—the publican was there, and a person behind the bar, and a little girl, who looked like a Jewess—she might have seen the paper given, and 1 think she did—I had read all the paper—there was not a great deal of it—I took the hair I sold to the pri
soner from a lot which I have—I dare say I have a cwt. and a half there now—I bought it in Cow-lane, just by Smithfield—I did not see any seal hair in that—if I want a lot of huir I send my man and pay for it.

MR. PARRY. Q. In what quantity do you purchase hair? A. It depends upon what job I have got—perhaps eight or ten cwt.—I never went on credit in my life for it—I generally deal at Bermondsey or Cow-cross—I built Nicholson's-wharf—the contract for that was some thousands of pounds—I am building now—I have had 200 men at work for me.
RICHARD HEADINGTYON . I was employed as foreman of the work in the Old Kent-road for Mr. Morgan—I had no conversation with him about the prisoner—he never told me he had contracted with the prisoner.

WILLIAM HOOK . I am a painter. I painted for Mr. Morgan in the com
morcial-road—the prisoner was working there as a plasterer—Mr. Morgan told me and the prisoner that he wanted us to go down to make a contract

for the work at Peckham—we went, and I contracted for the painting—I believe Taylor gave in a contract for the plastering—he and Morgan were two or three hours together—I heard no conversation between them.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Six Months.

1785.
EMMA WEBB was indicted for
stealing 100lbs. weight of lea
ther, value 5l., the goods of
Henry Warren Knox Coxhead, and
EDMUND WEBB
for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen.

HENRY WARREN KNOX COXHEAD . I am a leather-cutter, and live at Newington. The prisoners dealt at my shop—I am told they are not related—I missed some leather, and in'particular tome which was marked for springs—this is that piece, and I believe the whole of the leather that ifl here is mine.

JURY. Q. How do you know this? A. Here are the marks on it—the leather between each mark is wide enough to make a pair of women's soles—I described this to the officer before I inspected it—I never sell it marked in this manner—here are some pieces with a brand mark, which I can swear to.

MATILDA TENNANT . I am the niece of Mr. Coxhead. On the 31st of July he went out—Emma Webb came to purchase something—I had set a person to watch her—(I had seen her take leather previously, but I did not stop her)—on the 6th of Aug. Emma Webb came again—I showed her some black leather—I had served her with a quarter of a yard of union; and from what the girl told me, I went to the gate after her, and took this piece of leather from under her cloak—I had sold her a small piece of leather, but not this.
EMMA WEBB. I gave her some eggs for this piece of leather. Witness. No, not for this—she gave me two eggs for a small piece a month before.
MARIA MARTIN . I was set to watch the prisoner—I saw her take this leather from the board, and put it under her cloak—she went out—I brought her back, and Miss Tennant took it from under her cloak.
Emma Webb. I did not take it; I bought it in the street of a young man.

JAMES BURTON (police-constable M 277.) I went to Emma Webb's lodgings, at No. 1, Henry-street, Kent-street—I knew her before—I found Edmund Webb there, and a large quantity of leather—he said he had bought it of different tradesmen; one of them was Mr. Arnold, and he gave 22s. for some—I went to Mr. Arnold, and he denied it—I found some of this leather concealed under the bed, and some on a shelf.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Is not this the first time you ever named a single place as stated by him? A. No—I stated before the Magistrate that he said he bought it at particular places—I found him at work as a shoemaker, and there was leather about.

EMMA WEBB—
GUILTY . Aged 26.

EDMUND WEBB—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

1786.
MATTHEW HOPKINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of Aug., 6 tame pigeons, price 5s., the property of
Thomas Freeland; and that he had been before convicted of felony.
GEORGE WILLIAM FREELAND . I am fourteen years old—my father,

Thomas Freeland, lives in Smith-street, Camberwell. On the 13th of Aug., about five o'clock in the morning, I missed six pigeons from a pigeon-house at the back of my father's house—I had seen them safe at nine o'clock the night before—I have seen five of them since.

Cross-examined by MR. HUDDLKSTON. Q. Did you buy them? A. My father did—they were rather common—he had had them six months—they were in a dove-cote—they flew about, but they went in the cote at night, and were shut up.
JANE ATTWOOD . At half-past eight o'clock in the morning of the 13th of Aug. the prisoner brought me six tame pigeons—I bought them of him—five of them are here.
Cross-examined. Q. He told you a man named Jones sent him with them? A. Yes, and he said he lived in Thomas-street—he did not say Thomas-street, Kennington.
JOHN NEAL (police-constable P 30.) I took the prisoner—I said the charge was for taking some pigeons—he said, "Very well, I will go with you"—I produce the pigeons.
RICHARD DAVIES (police-constable P 55.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read—Convicted 18th March, 1844; confined three monthst and whipped)—the prisoner is the person.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined One Year.

1787.
EDWIN CLARK was indicted
for stealing 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 pair of trowsers, 3s.; 1 waistcoat, 2s.; 1 neckerchief, 1s.; 1 scarf, 4s.; 1 pair of boots, 5s.; 1 breast-pin, 10s.; 1 guard-chain, 3s.; 1 printed book, 1s.; and 1 bag, 1s.; the goods of
Reuben Hyams: also, 21 printed books, value 21l., the goods of
John Douglas Hopkins, his master; to both which he pleaded.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

1788.
ELIZABETH COBBETT was indicted
for stealing 1 bonnet, value 5s.; 1 gown, 14s.; 1 shawl, 8s.; 1 petticoat, 2s.; and 1 shift, 1s.; the goods of
William Edward Boyle, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

1789.
WILLIAM GIBBINGS was indicted
for stealing 1 half-crown, the money of
John Higgs, his master.

JOHN HIGGS . I live at the Canal-bridge, Old Kent-road, and am a cheesemonger; the prisoner was my shopman from the 21st of June, and continued so about five weeks. On Monday, the 28th of July, I desired twelve shillings and six half-crowns to be marked in my presence, which was done—they were put into the till between three and four o'clock that afternoon—I went to the till about ten that night, and took all the money out—I do not know what the total amount in the till was—there were six half-crowns there then, but two of them were not marked—two of the marked half-crowns were gone, and there were but three marked shillings left—I did not speak to the prisoner about it till the Wednesday, when I called a policeman in, and accused the prisoner of robbing me—he denied it, and was searched—he had a box at my house, which was locked—it was unlocked in my presence—in it were found ten sovereigns, and, I think,

16s. 6d. in silver—on looking it over I found one of the marked half-crowns—this is it—it is one that I had had marked—the prisoner had the key of the box—the officer took it from him—the prisoner said, if he had a marked half-crown, I must have given it to him—I had given him no half-crown.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You did not mark the money yourself? A. My wife marked it in my presence—I suspect the 10l. in gold, which was in the prisoner's box, was mine—I mean to lay hold of it, if the prisoner is convicted, if they will give it me—I opened my shop on the 21st of June—I have been a cheesemonger all my life—I have been unfortunate twice—I have been a bankrupt once—that is about five years ago—I cannot tell exactly what I paid—there were two dividends, and after that I paid a composition of 6s. in the pound—I opened my shop six months afterwards—I suspect the money in the prisoner's box was mine, and that it has been taken since I have been there—I have not jumped into a particularly good business—there was no agreement made with the prisoner for wages; I was to pay him what he deserved—I was to be the judge of that—if we had had any settlement I should perhaps have given him 1s. 6d. a week—I had not paid him at all, but that is not uncommon—I found him a living—I did not suppose I was taking a man who had not a penny in the world—if he had asked me for money he would have had it at once—I imagined he had money, certainly, or he would have asked me for it—I used to have money in the till, as soon as it was taken, not before, except coppers—if a person came in for change, the prisoner was to do what is generally done, send to a neighbour's shop for change—I should not have been very angry with him to have given change out of his own pocket, or if he had taken it again out of the till when silver came in—there was 2l. 19s. in all when I took it out at night—there was no gold nor 5s. pieces—I put in twelve shillings and six half-crowns—I can-not tell what there was in besides—I had not been to the prisoner's box before I took him into custody—I might have seen it—I certainly had not looked into it, nor bad any one by my direction—one thing which caused my suspicion was hearing him rattle his money of a night after he went to bed.

JOHN TREFFORD (police-constable P 176.) On the 81st of July Mr. Higgs gave the prisoner into my charge, and accused him of robbing him—he said he had not—I found on his person a half-crown and 1 1/2d.—Mr. Higgs asked him if he had any money in his box—he said, "Yes, ten sovereigns and some silver"—I took the key of his box from him in search-ing him—I found in his box ten sovereigns, and 18s. 6d. in silver, and amongst it this half-crown, which Mr. Higgs said he could swear to, and to his wife's marking it in his presence—the prisoner said, if he had any marked money, he must have got it in giving change.

JAMES CADBURY . I am a cheesemonger. The prisoner lived with me about two months—I know of his coming from the country to settle here—I know he had ten sovereigns—he came to me on the Friday, and let me have the ten sovereigns on the Monday—a fortnight after, he went to Mr. Higgs I returned it to his brother, to put into the bank for him—he was a steady, respectable, honest person, while with me.
FRANCIS GIBBINGS . I am the prisoner's brother. I received from Mr.

Cadbury ten sovereigns, on the 5th of July, to put into the savings-bank—I took it there, but the clerk said my brother must be there to enter hii name himself—I returned the ten sovereigns to my brother the same evening.
NOT GUILTY .

1789.
JAMES BRUSH was indicted
for stealing 3 half-crowns, I shil
ling, 1 groat, and three halfpence; the monies of
William Hines.

WILLIAM HINES . I am a brickmaker, and live at Battersea. The pri
soner worked in the same field. Last Saturday night I took him to ray house to sleep, because he was very much intoxicated—I was sober—we got home about half-past ten o'clock at night—I counted my money—I had three half-crowns, one shilling, a fourpenny piece, and three halfpence—I put the three half-crowns in one of my jacket pockets, to pay the rent—I put the shilling in another pocket, and the rest of the money in ano-ther pocket, but all in my jacket—I put my jacket at the foot of the stairs—I went to bed, and did not awake till a quarter past eight; but the night before the prisoner made a mistake and went into my bed, and my wife called me to turn him out, which I did, and he left his clothes down stairs—in the morning I found my jacket, but it was removed from where I left it, and the money was gone—I saw the prisoner several hours after
wards, and asked him to return the money—he denied having it.

DAVID NOBLE . I lodge at Hines's house. On Saturday night the pri
soner slept with me, but I went to bed first, and was asleep when he came up—I got up at half-past seven the next morning—the prisoner went down first—as I went down I saw the prisoner at the foot of the stairs, picking up some money—I heard it chink, and saw some white and brown pieces—he then went to the water-closet—he was the first person down stairs, and sent me to fetch his own clothes—I did not see any jacket—it was removed.
Prisoner. Q. Were we not on the stairs together? A. You went down first—I was on the stairs when I saw you picking up the money.

JOHN SHARP . The prisoner worked for me——I paid him last Saturday night 17s. 3d.—he lodged with me, and he paid me 3s. 8d.—he did not lodge with me that night—he came home on Sunday morning, but I was not at home till Sunday night—I had gone to Woolwich after I paid him—I did not find anything in his jacket; my wife did.

ELIZA SHARP . The prisoner lodged at my husband's—he paid me 3s. on the Sunday morning, beside what he had paid to my husband—he brought home some victuals, which was worth about 4s.—he had a pair of second-hand shoes on his feet, and told me he had bought a little book—I was looking, and found 5s. wrapped up in the book—I put it back, and the policeman took it away on the Monday afternoon.
JAMES MURPHY (police-constable V 261.) I took the prisoner—I found on him 1s. 6d. in silver, and 5 1/2d. in coppers.
Prisoner. I never saw the jacket, and never had the money; what I had was my own.
JURY to JOHN SHARP. Q. What money did you pay the prisoner? A. Some half-crowns, some shillings, and some halfpence—I had 2l. worth of half-crowns, and paid them all some half-crowns and other money.
NOT GUILTY .

1790.
THOMAS BATT was indicted
for stealing 1 rule, value 6s. 6d., the goods of
John Pegrum, his master.

JOHN PEGRUM . I am a carpenter, and live in Robert-atreet, Brixton—the prisoner worked in my service. I missed a rule, which I had laid on the stone pavement where we were at work—I spoke to the prisoner about it—he said he did not believe I had had a rule there that morning—this it my rule.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you hear of it from Randall? A. Yes—I expect I had laid the rule on the pavement—the prisoner came about nine or ten o'clock, and I missed the rule about one.

WILLIAM RANDALL . I saw the prisoner have the rule between eleven and twelve o'clock that morning—he said he had found it in the drain—he afterwards said he had sold it for 1s. and told me not to say anything about it.
Cross-examined. Q. He showed it you? A. Yes—I saw it was my master's—I told him so, and read the name on it—he then said, "Don't say anything about it."
JOHN PERKINS . I bought the rule for 10d. of the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you rub it with sand-paper, to erase the name? A. Yes—I do not know the name—I cannot read.

JOHN PEGRUM
re-examined. This rule had my name on it—it is partly erased, but you can see it now.
RICHARD WEBB (police-constable P 228.) I took the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. In going to the station, did he not say he knew where the rule was, he would get it back, and you need not take him up? A. Yes—he said he found it down the drain, and he thought all he found he could do as he liked with.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 32.—Recommended to mercy.—
Confined Six Days.

1791.
ROBERT WHITBY, alias John Rock
, was indicted
for stealing 3 feet of leaden pipe, value 1s., the goods of
William Baker, and fixed to a building; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

FRANCES JANE BAKER . I live with my father, William Baker, who keeps a beer-shop—the prisoner was a customer—he was there between three and four o'clock in the afternoon, on the 8th of Aug.—we had a piece of leaden pipe at the end of the passage—I saw the prisoner pat it into his pocket, and go away—it has not been found since—I am quite sure I saw him take it.

Prisoner. Q. Why did not you stop me? A. My mother and father both being out, I had two businesses to attend to, and it quite slipped my memory—my father missed some taps, and he asked me about the pipe—I told him I saw the prisoner put it in his left-hand pocket—I swear he took it.

CHARLES JOHN ROPER . I was in the house—I went into the ground to play at skittles—I saw the prisoner come, take two pieces of lead
pipe in his hand, and leave the ground—I thought he was a plumber.

Prisoner's Defence. I was passing the house, and was called in, and saw Baker's brother—he asked me to drink—I stopped there two or three hours—they were cheating a lad at cards—I mentioned it, and Baker got
up, and said, "You don't want your head punched?"—I know nothing about the pipe.
WILLIAM HOBBS . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction, by the name of John Rock—(read—Convicted 20th March, 1843, and confined three months)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY .* Aged 27.—
Confined One Year.

1792.
GEORGE WILLIAMS was indicted
for stealing 4 account-books, value 10s.; and 2 book-covers, 1s.; the goods of
Joseph Brook Hunt and another, his masters; to which he pleaded

1793.
PETER CHRISTOPHER RING
was charged, on the Coroner's Inquisition only, with feloniously killing and slaying
James Anderson.

WILLIAM TOLLER . I live in Southwark. On the night of the 13th of July, at half-past twelve o'clock, I was returning home—the deceased and the prisoner and two women were quarrelling in the street—I stopped to listen—they got to high words—the quarrel appeared to rest between the prisoner's wife and the deceased, the prisoner not saying a word—I heard the deceased call the prisoner's wife a b—y w—the prisoner then said, "If you call my wife a w—again, I will knock you down"—the word occurred again, and then the prisoner raised his arm, and the man fell—I assisted him up, and the prisoner assisted—I said, "You have killed the man"—he said, "I hope I have not"—I said, "You had better run fora doctor," which he did, and as we were taking the deceased to the hospital the doctor met us, and said, "Take him to the hospital directly."

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Might not the deceased have stepped back to avoid the blow, and have stumbled? A. I cannot say—they were tipsy—I saw the prisoner's arm raised—whether it was a push or a blow I cannot tell.

MARY ANN RYDER . I was going on an errand—I heard Mr. Anderson call the prisoner's wife a w—several times, and she called him a d—d vagabond and a rogue—the prisoner then said if he called his wife a w—again he would knock him down—the prisoner then raised his arm, and gave him a push or a blow—he was struck, but I cannot say whether it was with his hand or his fist.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you quite certain he was touched at all, or might he have stumbled back? A. I am quite certain he was touched—I was standing about a yard off, at the corner of the street—there were not many people—I did not see Toller till the deceased was down—the de-ceased did not step back when the prisoner lifted his hand.

ELIZABETH BRITTON . I had been with Mr. and Mrs. Ring—I had not seen the deceased—we were coming down the street, and two or three words occurred, but I do not know about what—I walked on before them—I saw no blow.
RICHARD WHEATLEY (police-constable 161.) I saw no blow—I saw the man bleeding, helped him up, and took him to the hospital.

WILLIAM SEDGWICK SANDEN . I am a surgeon. I was at St. Thomas'i Hospital when the man was brought in, bleeding very profusely over the left temple, as if from a fall, not by a blow—he was insensible for five days, and then died—the cause of his death was the full.
Cross-examined. Q. It was the rupture of a blood-vessel on the brain, was it not? A. Yes, one of the principal vessels—I do not think a blow on the head would have occasioned the mischief.
NOT GUILTY .

1794.
GEORGE HARE,
JOHN PAYNE,
WILLIAM GOOD-RIGHT,
JAMES GOODRIGHT,
HENRY GOODRIGHT,
JAMES FLINN,
WILLIAM PASSFIELD ,
MICHAEL MANNIX,
alias Cornelius Mannix
, and
JOHN SHAE , were indicted for
assaulting
Thomas Wigzell, a peace-officer, in the execution of his office.—2nd COUNT, with intent to resist the lawful apprehension and detainer of the said George Hare.

EDWARD KAYSER (police-constable P 121.) On Sunday, the 22nd of June, about half-past eight o'clock in the evening, I was on duty in the Caraberwell-road—I went into Windmill-lane, and saw Hare and Payne, and a great many other persons—Hare was rather drunk, and was stripped to fight—I requested him to go away—he said he should when he liked; but when he found I was desirous for him to go, he went, and the people separated after a few minutes—some time afterwards I received information, and went to Nelson-street, and saw Hare throwing up his hat and jacket, and there were fifty or more persons about—I went to the Walworth-road, and got Wigzell—when we got to the bottom of Windmill-lane we saw Chantler at a distance, and beckoned him—when we got to Nelson-street I saw Hare in fustian or corded trowsers—he had no coat or waistcoat on—his shirt-sleeves were tucked up, and his handkerchief tied round his waist—he was throwing up his hat and jacket, and challenging any one to fight—he challenged several in my presence—he did not speak to one alone—I went up to him with Wigzell, and said he must go to the station—he wanted to know what for—I said he would know that when he got to the station—he went a short distance very quietly, then turned very restive indeed—I requested him to go quietly, and told him we were taking him to the station—he requested to know the charge—I said, "Being drunk and disorderly, and creating a disturbance"—he said he would not go, life or death first—he laid himself down on the ground seve-ral times—after we got a short distance Payne came up and caught hold of Hare by the braces and shirt, and said he would be d—d if he should go; he should go along with him—I told Payne to take his hands off him, or I would break his arms with my truncheon—he continued to hold on to Hare several times after that—Hare laid himself down on the ground, and said, if we would allow him to button his shirt up, he would go quietly—I had seen him kick out several times before that—we allowed him to get up, and he was about buttoning his shirt, when he clenched hit, fist, struck me in the face, and made my nose bleed—he struck Wigzell, who very nearly fell, but he held on by Hare, and kept himself up—I then drew my truncheon, and struck Hare on the head, who fell to the ground—when Hare struck me in the face my truncheon was in my pocket—there was a hooting and shouting of the people, and a singing out to Hare not to go with us—he got up, and struggled, and the mob all closed in upon us—we were being overpowered, and I went to the corner of Wind-mill-lane, to get more assistance—Wigzell and Chantler remained with Hare—I returned with three other officers in about three minutes—Hare

had then escaped—Wigzell was in a very bad state—he complained of having been very ill-treated while I was gone—I saw the prisoner Shae there at the first beginning—he wanted to fight with Hare, and asked my permission so to do—I said I could not grant it.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. When Payne came up did not he say, "Don't go with them, Tom; go home quietly?" A. "Come along with me" was what he said—he might say, "Go home quietly"—Wigzell said, "You had better let him alone, or you will get locked up yourself"—I am positive Hare is the person who was there, I took such particular notice of him—he was down on the ground four or five times—he might have been on one occasion knocked down by a blow with a truncheon, but I did not see it—I did not strike him on the shin with my truncheon—I struck him on the head—I do not recollect hearing Payne say, when he had hold of Hare's braces, "Are you going to kill the man?"—we took Hare for being drunk, throwing up his hat and jacket, and wanting to fight.
MR. CLARK. Q. Do you mean that Hare was knocked down four or five times? A. I did not say he was knocked down, only when I struck him on the head—the other times he threw himself down.

THOMAS WIGZELL (police-constable P 137.) I went with Kayser to Nelson-street—I saw Hare there—I never saw him before—he was throw-ing up his jacket, and was stripped to his shirt, wanting to fight somebody—Kayser told him to go quietly—he said he would not—then Kaysef took him, and I assisted him—Hare asked us both several times why we were taking him—Kayser said, "For being drunk and disorderly"—he said he would not go, and he kicked me first in Nelson-street—I drew my staff, and told him if he kicked me again I would break his legs—when he got round the corner out of Nelson-street he struck me in the face with his fist—he struck me five or six times in the face, and kicked me several times on my right leg—Kayser struck him—neither of us had struck him before he had struck both of us in the face—I should say there were up wards of 200 persons present—I saw Payne there—he came up to Hare, and said, "Tom, go home; don't go with them"—I said he had better mind his own business, or he would get locked up himself—he then took hold of Hare by the braces, and said he would be d—d if he should go, and struck me in the fate—soon after this Kayser went away, and when he was gone Hare struck me in the face with his clenched fist—when I took my staff out I had kept it in my hand, but I had not used it up to this time—Chantler was at this time with me—the people got in between Hare and us to rescue him—I am certain Henry, James, and William Goodright were amongst the persons who assisted at the rescue—when Hare struck me in the face, I struck him across the shoulders with my truncheon, and knocked him down; and I struck him on the feet when he was on the ground kicking, to keep his kicks from me, when he was trying to kick me in the privates—he did not kick me there, but he was aiming at that part—I had known the three Goodrights before, and they got between Hare and me—one of them got hold of me, but I could not say which—Hare knocked me down, and I was kicked and jumped upon—I lay insensible on the ground several minutes—I was kicked in my side and the back of my head—there were many of the mob besides the prisoners interfering at that time—Hare got away from me—I got up and tried to follow him, and I was knocked down by a man who is not here—I got up, and went to

strike the man, and was knocked down by Payne—I suppose I was being beat for a quarter of an hour—the riot lasted an hour—I have been ill ever since, and have not been on duty—I spat blood for some time, and I do now at times.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How can you say it was Hare? A. Because I am sure it was him—that was the first time I had seen him—I think it was twice he was knocked down by blows from truncheons, first by Kayser and then by me—I think he was not knocked down by Chantler—I had seen Payne before, and knew him well—when he came up he said, "Don't go with them, go home quietly"—he did not say to. me, "If you will let him go, he will go quietly home with me"—I did not hear the police say, "We must take him to the station"—Kayser told Hare that if he would go quietly to the station he thought the inspector would not take the charge—I think I said to Hare, "If you bite me again I will knock your brains out"—he had got my hand in his mouth then—I put one of my knees on his chest to keep him down after that—he was drunk—I cannot distinguish any thing particular that William Goodright did, only the rescue.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON Q. Was this rescue at the latter part of the transaction? A. Yes—I had received several blows then—one of the Good rights touched Hare, but I cannot tell which, they were all there—I could not say how many were assisting in the rescuing—there might be nearly twenty.

NICHOLAS CHANTLER (police-constable P 224). I went with Wigzell and Kayser to Nelson-street—I saw the officers and Hare there—I saw Flinn, and while I was assisting Wigzell to take Hare, Flino took hold of my belt and struck me with his oilier hand—no one else struck me to my knowledge—I have known him about a year and a half, and am sure it was him—I think he had hold of my belt for a minute and a half—I had got hold of Hare at the time, who was kicking and fighting, and very riotous—Payne was there, he took hold of my truncheon, and said "You b—r, you mean to kill the man"—that was because I struck Hare on the leg with my truncheon, because he kicked Wigzell—a person named May came to assist me, and at that very time I was separated from Wigsell—I should think Wigzell was alone four or five minutes.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. When you went to Nelson-street, you found Wigzell aid Kayser had got Hare in custody? A. They said they were going to take him into custody, and he resisted—they had got him, one on each side, and I went behind and pushed him—the people were peaceable then, but when we got some distance the people said, "Don't go"—I swear that Hare kicked Wigzell above his knee, and then I struck Hare on the legs.
COURT. Q. Was it necessary for your brother officer's defence for you to strike him? A. It was necessary—I did forbear as long as I could.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. What time was this? A. I should think it wanted twenty minutes to nine o'clock—it was getting a little dark—I should think there were 250 people—I had seen Flinn about Camberwell before, the same as other people—there were two or three females about—what Flinn did was to take hold of my belt and pull me away—I am sure it was him—he had taken no part in the transaction be
fore, only pushing—all the people were pushing one another.

THOMAS MANLEY I am a cork-cutter, and live in Windmill-lane, Cam
berwell—on

Sunday night, the 22nd of June, I was at home—I saw Wig-zell and Kayser in Windmill-lane, and Hare in custody—I did not hear Hare say anything then, but when Payne came and took hold of his braces and said, "Don't go," Hare said, "I will be d—d if I will go"—I knew Payne before, but I did not know Hare—I saw Eliza Norman strike Wigzell—she is the wife, or lives as a wife with William Passfield—when she struck Wigzell he turned round with a random blow and struck her on the neck or the back part of the head—that was after several ups and downs with Payne and Hare, and Wigzell was getting exhausted, Passfield came off the foot-path and struck Wigzell two or three times with his fists on the back part of his person—I saw the three. Goodrights there, Flinn, Pass-field, Mannix, and Shae—I saw Flinn have hold of the officer's belt, pull-ing him across, and striking him—Mannix had hold of his belt at the same time, and another person who is not in custody—I saw Wigzell on the ground, and Payne had hold of Chantler's staff—I went in and saw William Goodright stamping on Wigzell as he lay on the ground—I went to assist, and I heard some one say, "There is the b—y cork-cutter gone to help the Peelers"—James and Henry Goodright were edging in against the officer, and Shae was inciting Hare on, and saying, "Go it, Tom—give it him, Tom."

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Are you a master or journeyman? A. A master—my shop is at No. 16, Windmill-lane—I went to see that my brother was safe—I was sober—I have never been in the police—I never was a witness but once before, which was at Horsemonger-lane—Payne took hold of Hare by the braces and endeavoured to get him away—I believe he said, "Don't go, go along with me."

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did you know the Goodrights? A. Yes—Passfield was standing on the raised foot-path by the side of the road—there was a number of people there—there was not a depth of two peo
ple between Passfield and the officers—sometimes there was a large space of twenty yards round the officers, and sometimes not three yards.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. Was Wigzell close by you when Shae used the words? A. No, he was at a distance from me—Chantler was in the same row with him—I do not know whether Kayser was gone for the other officers—I did not see any female hold of Shae's arm—there were several females about—I did not see them talking to him—there were three persons taken beside the prisoners—Jarvis was one, and two other Goodrights—I thought Jarvis was one, and when I saw his brother I thought otherwise—the prisoner, Mannix's brother, Cornelius, was taken up, I believe, on my representation—he was discharged—to the best of my belief Michael Mannix was in the crowd—I am certain of it—I was standing in Windmill-lane, close to Mr. Wills's floor-cloth factory—I might be ten or twelve yards from Shae—the riot lasted from half-past seven till half-past eight o'clock—it was about a quarter past eight o'clock when Shae said what he did—I had dined at home—I had not a cup extra—I was near falling into a ditch in supporting my brother who was intox-icated.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did you see either of the Goodrights with a child in his arms? A. Yes, I believe it was Henry—I was always on the raised foot-way—the policeman was dragged into the footway.

MR. CLARK. Q. Did you see what time Henry Goodright had the child? A. About a quarter before eight o'clock—I did not see him after
wards
with it—I understood this prisoner, Mannix's name was Cornelius, which caused the mistake—I had no doubt about the prisoner at all.

CHARLES ADAMS . I am a cabinet-maker. I saw the policemen ende
avour to persuade Hare to go to the station, telling him the inspector would not take the charge.
COURT. Q. Was there any violence on the part of the police before they were struck by Hare and Payne? A. No.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did not Payne say, "If you will let him go he will go home quietly with me?" A. Yes, a great number of times—I found Hare in custody—there was a bit of a struggle after Payne laid hold of Hare's braces—Hare lay on his back, and folded hit arms, and said they should carry him if they wanted him, or words to that effect—one of the officers went for a stretcher—Hare was on the ground several times, and Wigzell had his knee on his chest one time—they threw Hare down, and one of the policemen struck him, and some of them called out, "You bad better kill the man at once"—they called them butchers—Hare had nothing in his hand—I cannot tell whether he was drunk—I never saw him before—when he was down, and Wigzell had got his knee upon him, a woman came up.

CHARLES BARDONS (police-sergeant P 23.) I took Hare—I told him what for—he said he was not there—I said I should certainly take him, and he certainly was there—he said, "Well, to tell you the truth, I was tbere, but 1 was drunk."
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you take him on the 24th of June? A. Yes, at half-past three o'clock in the morning, in bed—he was very violent

JOHN WILLS (police-constable P 187.) I took Mannix—he asked what charge I had against him—I told him there was a warrant for his appre
hension for an assault on Wigzell, and a riot—he said, "You d----d rascal, you have picked me out at last, have you?—I was taking him to the station—he said he had been out of the way for tome time, and be would have been out of the way then if he had known—just before I got him to the station, he said I had got the wrong man, that his name was not Cornelius, but Michael—I had got the warrant, and I called him cor
nelius.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. He was drunk while you had this conversation? A. Yes, his brother was not taken then—he has been since—I took the prisoner on the 20th of July—he said, the next day, "I was drunk, and I dare say I did say what you represent, but I said it out of bravado."
JOHN JAMES STEADMAN (police-constable P 151.) I took Shae—he was drunk—he denied being there at the time of the'disturbance, and said he was miles away.

JOHN SWAN FLOWER . I am surgeon to the P division of police—I was called on the 23rd of June to attend Wigzell—he was labouring under excessive pain in his chest and abdomen—he spat blood—he was in great danger, and he is still—he will be quite incapable of performing his duty—his bladder is injured—he is forced to get out of bed every five or ten minutes—it will be a long time, if he ever does recover—he is in such pain he is glad to get into any position for relief.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was he in a good state of health before? A. Yes, I have had him before for fatigue only—we are obliged
sometimes to allow the men to put themselves on the sick list when they are tired out.

LUCY CHAPPELL . I was there that night, and saw tho beginning of the affair—Flinn was not there at first—he came afterwards, and the mob passed up to him—I, being a cripple, stood aside—Flinn came and stood by me—he did not move from me—he did not put his hand into a police
man's belt—he could not have done that without my seeing him—he stood by my side all the time.
MR. CLARK. Q. How long did you remain? A. I stood at the corner of Nelson-street about a quarter of an hour, and during that time Flinn stood by my side.

----MARTIN. I live at No. 2, Nelson-street. The first I saw was Hare in the field, challenging any one to fight—he then came back, went up Nelson-street, and I went home—I saw Flinn there, but he was not within 100 yards of the disturbance—I passed him more than twice or thrice—he was talking to a lame young woman—he was not near enough to put his hand into a policeman's belt.

MR. CLARK. Q. Did this take place opposite your window? A. No, I was at the door when the people first ran past—there was a disturbance and a fight in Grosvenor-court—I went out to see them—the policeman would not let them fight—I came back to my own door, and they passed me towards the Windmill public-house—I was at my door when they passed, and when they came back from the field too—that was not the time I saw Flinn—I went into Windmill-lane and saw Flinn when the mob was by the oil cloth factory—he was coining up Nelson-street—he was alone—they were then trying to get Hare.

CHARLES HUSSEY . I live at No. 5, Appleton-place. I am the letter-carrier of that district, and have been so for sixteen years—Michael Mannix lodges there—he was at home all that evening till eight o'clock—I was there till eight o'clock, and then I went out.
COURT. Q. How far is this from the Windmill? A. Half a mile.

ELIZABETH MILLER . I live at No. 5, Appleton-place, in the house where Michael Mannix lives. I was there on Sunday evening, the 22nd of June—I went to bed about ten o'clock—I had come home at four o'clock in the afternoon, and did not go out at all that evening—Mannix and his wife did not go out all that evening—my father and mother occupy the two rooms up stairs, and Mannix and his wife the two roomi down stairs—I was up and down sufficiently to know that Mannix did not leave the house—I saw Mr. Hussey there.

SARAH CATLIN . I am single, and live in Thomas-street. I go out washing and ironing—I saw James Goodright with a child in his arms on this occasion—I gave the child to him—I was there during the whole time—I saw the mob go past me—the three Goodrights were standing close by me, at a distance off from the row, and James Goodright had the child.

MR. CLARK. Q. When did you give him the child? A. It was his own child—I was walking with it—I gave it him and said, "Stand by me, and you will not get into any trouble"—he put the child on bis shoulder and stood by me—it was about eight o'clock when I gavo it him—I remained thero about a quarter of an hour or more—he took the
child home, and I went home with him—he was not in the crowd, and took no part in the disturbance.

HARE—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

W. GOODRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

PAYNE.—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Nine Months.

J. GOODRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

H. GOODRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

FLINN—
GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

PASSFIELD—
GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Two Months.

SHAE—
GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined One Month.

MANNIX—
NOT GUILTY .

1795.
EDWARD CLARK was indicted
for embezzling 1l. 3d. 3d., and 1l. 13s., which he had received on account of
John Booth, to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Six Months.

1796.
JOSEPH HARVEY was indicted
for feloniously killing, and slaying
Charles Ratherbee.
MR. PAYNE. conducted the Prosecution.

ANN RATHERBEE . I am the widow of Charles Ratherbee—he died on the 30th of July—he was a trumpeter, and lived in Lorinier-lane, Wal-worth—he rented a piece of ground of Mr. Westbrook, and let a piece of it to the prisoner. On the 8th of April I went out at the back door, and saw the prisoner sowing seeds in that ground—I told my husband—I then went and said to the prisoner, "My husband says it is useless for you to sow soed in that ground, for we want it to plant potatoes"—he said, "I will see him d—d first before I will give it up"—I returned to the cottage—my husband went out and told him it was no use for him to sow his seed, as he wanted it himself to plant potatoes; and how foolish it was of him to be so obstinate—the prisoner said, "You do, do you; I will tee you d—d before I will give it up"—my husband said, "The ground I want, and the ground I will have"—the prisoner said, "I will not give it up without it is by law"—he had bad a notice to quit the ground, and told my husband that be ought to have a twelvemonths' notice, not six—my husband said he never knew a twelvemonths' notice, six months' notice was always good in law—the prisoner said he would not give it up, and my husband said he should—the prisoner then said he would have a fair up and down for it—I suppose he meant a fight—he said, "You ought to have taken possession of the ground"—my husband said, "I am always in possession of my own ground while my cottage stands on it"—when my husband first went on the ground and spoke to the prisoner, he went a little distance, raised his arm, and drove his left elbow into my husband's chest, and threw him flat on his back—my husband had not done anything to him before he did that—I cried out, and said, "Oh, Mr. Hurvey, you will kill my husband!"—my husband got up, and said, "What did you do that for?"—the prisoner said, "If you don't stand out of my way I will knock your b—y life out!" and the prisoner's niece said "He did not knock your husband down, he only pushed him down"—when my husband said he was always in possession while bis cottage stood on it, the prisoner said that was not possession, my husband ought to have

come and put his spade in the ground—I went in and fetched a spade—my hnsband took and stuck it in the ground, and said, "Now 1 have taken possession"—the prisoner took the spade out of the ground, and said, "Then you mean it, you b—r, do you?" and made a blow at my husband with it—my husband took up a rake to defend himself, a scuffle ensued, my husband stooped, and the spade went over his head into our ground—he was still on the ground, and the prisoner took hold of him with both his hands by the collar—(my husband had not got the rake then, it had dropped from his hand)—the prisoner dragged him along the ground, and tore his waistcoat off his back—my husband got up and told me to fetch a policeman—I said I would not leave him, I was afraid of his being murdered—by that time Mr. Harvey's niece came up with a bull-dog, which she loosened from the kennel and brought to the space between his ground and ours—she said, "Look, Pitcher, at Fop, the fiddler, you could make a better man than him"—my husband took up a couple of bricks and said he would throw them at the dog—Mr. Brush came up—my husband took up his waistcoat, and said, "See what he has done"—Mr. Brush said, "It serves you right, it would have been a good job if he had killed you; you ought to have given him a proper notice"—my hus-band said he had—there were no blows given after that—the prisoner stood in a fighting attitude, and said, "Come on, you pretty little boy, I will fight you with one hand"—I said, "No, he can't fight, he has not been brought up to that blackguard calling"—my husband was thirty-three years old—he had not been suffering at all, that 1 know of—when we got in he told me he was very sick—I gave him the basin, and be threw up about a pint of blood—I gave him vinegar and water, which stopped it, but it came on again the same day about twelve, and Mr. Otway was called in—the bleeding continued from that time, now and then, till he died—he was in Guy's Hospital a week and five days—he did not strike the prisoner at all.

ELIZABETH WIFFIN . I live in Hen and Chicken
Jane, Walworth. This matter happened on a Tuesday morning—I lived next door to Mr. Ratherbee's cottage, on the right hand—I saw Harvey sowing seed—I saw Mrs. Ratherbee go up to him, and I heard her say, "Mr. Harvey, my husband has sent me to tell you it is not any use your sowing seeds in the ground, for we want it to plant potatoes in"—the prisoner said, "I will see him d—d first"—she went into the cottage—Mr. Ratherbee and she came out—they went straight to the prisoner, and Mr. Ratherbee said, "Mr. Harvey, what is the use of being so foolish not to give up the ground? you have had a regular notice six months, why do you want twelve months?"—the prisoner said, "I will have twelve months"—Mr. Ratherbee said, "A six months' written notice is quite plenty by law"—the prisoner said, "I will not give it up unless by law"—Mr. Ratherbee said, "I do not want to go to law, I have no money to go to law; all I want is for you to give up the ground by peace and quietness"—I then saw the prisoner go from Mr. Ratherbee—he stooped, and picked up a stick, which appeared to me to be about six inches long—he was marking the beds of seed with it—I then went into my cottage for a cup of coffee, and as I got up to return I looked through the window, and saw the pri
soner going towards Mr. Ratherbee with his left elbow up—in passing to the door I lost sight of them for a moment, and did not see the blow struck—when

I got out I found Mr. Ratherbee flat on his back—the prisoner was about a yard away, looking over Mr. Ratherbee—Mrs. Ratberbee said, "Oh, Mr. Harvey, what did you do that for? you will kill my poor husband"—Mr. Ratherbee got up, and said, "What did you do that for? what did you strike me for?"—the prisoner said, using an awful expres-sion, "I did not strike you, I only pushed you"—Mr. Ratherbee said, "You did strike me, you did not push me; I can feel the blow"—Harvey said, "I did not strike you, I only pushed you; I have witnesses to prow it"—I saw a spade in the ground—I cannot say who put it there, and I saw a rake lying down—I saw Mr. Harvey take up the spade to make a blow at Mr. Ratherbee—Mr. Ratherhee stooped down, picked up this rake, and held it across his face, and said, "Do you mean it?"—Mr. Harvey used an awful expression in reply, and threw the spade—Mr. Ratherbee stooped down, and it went over his bead, and went right into Mr. Ratherbee's ground—after that Mr. Brush came up.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. You say you were standing at your door? A. Yes—I cannot say how far I was from the place—I heard all that passed—I did not come to the prisoner and say that I would come as a witness on his behalf—I saw this transaction from first to last, except when I went in for the coffee—my grandfather was there, but he was not with me all the time—he saw great part of it—we were all at breakfast.
MR. PAYNE. Q. Where was your grandfather? A. Sometimes inside, and sometimes out—I do not suppose he saw above half of it.

CHARLES WILLIAM OTWAY . I live in Canterbury-row, and am a sur
geon.
